title: Will a member of the National League for Democracy (NLD) take office as president of Myanmar before April 2016?
preds:
Just a senseless but incredible funny follow-up on the time zone and daylight saving - debate:

Reaffirming btw.

This has become, interestingly, a trick question. The new president IS NLD. That's not anywhere in dispute. HOWEVER, he is slated to take office... April 1st, 2016. So, if we go by the letter of the question, the correct answer is... no. 100%. Since April 1st is April, even though we may be predicting the correct party, the fact that the new president won't be sworn in till April 1st means the "correct" predictive answer is... NO. Perhaps I'm reading too much into this? I suppose only time, and the hit to my brier score, will tell.

I would plum for 100% given the recent election victory. However, there were on-going conflicts as recently as February 2015 and assassinations aren't entirely unheard of (though they are an exceptionally low-probability event). There could also be more prosaic issues which introduce delays into the process of taking office. Again, these are very low-probability events -- I can't even think of any off the top of my head. 99% ? Does 1% lee-way fit? I guess we'll see.

per wsjcom 6.42 PM PST  a summary from a post there  from WSJ "stringer" in Ragoon, Burma YANGON, Myanmar—A newly elected legislature will nominate this country’s new president Thursday in a selection process that is testing the delicate relationship between the still-powerful military and the democracy movement led by Aung San Suu Kyi, whose party dominates parliament. Ms. Suu Kyi is constitutionally barred from being a candidate. But her National League for Democracy is expected to use its overwhelming legislative majority to install a candidate from its ranks who is likely to have little of Ms. Suu Kyi’s stature and whom she has already stated she will control from behind the scenes.
The new president will be the first to lead a democratically elected government whose leaders are untainted by military links since the armed forces seized power in 1962. The new government follows a nominally civilian transition regime of former generals who ruled from 2011 but were defeated in the November election in which the NLD swept both houses of parliament. The NLD hasn’t said who it will offer up as a candidate, and party leaders have offered only vague clues. Win Htein, a central executive committee member, has said that Ms. Suu Kyi “cannot be president” and has suggested only that the candidate’s name will have two words. A name that has been floated is Htin Kyaw, an Oxford graduate, senior party member and son-in-law of NLD co-founder U Lwin. Another potential candidate is Tin Oo, a former co-leader of the party and onetime general, who is almost 90 and frail. Speculation has also turned to Ms. Suu Kyi’s personal physician, Tin Myo Win, or her personal secretary and closest confidant, Tin Mar Aung. Mr. Tin Oo has previously insisted that Ms. Suu Kyi must be president. None of the others has commented.
“In general, it is not that important who the president is, as long as it is the right kind of person—someone who follows instructions from Aung San Suu Kyi,” said Richard Horsey, a Yangon-based analyst. “But if it is someone who ruffles the feathers of the military or develops ideas different from hers, then it matters a lot.”
end quote wsj,com asai (c) News corp.

@clinton - I found what I was looking for.  Not concerned about time zones.  A tiny bit of history.  President Obama has been sworn in three times.   How can he have had three when he has only had two terms?  Chief Justice Roberts screwed up the first oath in 2009.  The wording was wrong but President Obama followed along and said the wrong words.  Embarrassing to say the least.  Later that night, out of an abundance of caution, the CJ and President redid the oath without mistakes.  I believe the President signed either legislation or an executive order again also out of an abundance of caution.   Most Constitutional law experts said the second oath was unnecessary because the U.S. Constitution says the President begins the term on January 20th at noon.  By operation of law, President Obama became President at noon on January 20, 2009.  Nothing, even botched oaths, can affect that. That makes a lot of sense.  No country ever wants there to be even a second that they do not have a President (or equivalent).  I think that is a fair statement of government and one that is important in my analysis of this question.  The continuation of a stable government is the goal here.  Based on President Obama’s multiple oaths and what I know about the U.S. system, I wondered what the Myanmar Constitution says about Presidential terms.  Granted, there is system is different and they do not have a set day and time like the U.S., but my same thoughts apply to their President’s start time. The relevant portions of their Constitution say:   60. (a) The President shall be elected by the Presidential Electoral College. And  61. (a) The term of office of the President or the Vice-Presidents is five years.
(b) After the expiry of the incumbent term, the President and the Vice-Presidents
shall continue their duties until the time the new President is duly elected.
(c) The President and the Vice-Presidents shall not serve more than two terms.
(d) An interim period to serve as the President or the Vice-President shall not
be counted as one term of office.
(e) If a vacancy is filled for the President or the Vice-President for any reason,
the term of office of the new President or the new Vice-President shall be up
to the expiry of the original term of office. Let us assume that they do in fact elect a President from the NLD prior to the expiration of the current term.   According to the link from @Clinton, the last President assumed office on March 30, 2011.  So at midnight on March 30, 2016, if there is a duly elected President, he or she “takes office” or assumes the Presidency by operation of law, just like President Obama in 2009.  When the swearing in, banquet, and party are scheduled for do not matter.   Back to 99%.

A note on the April 1 issue.  The close time is April 1 at 1:59 AM [in my time zone] - which is about 3:29 PM on April 1 in Myanmar (I may be off an hour or two because of daylight savings).  I contacted GJP back in January to see if close time=forecasting window.  Here's my message and the two responses: Can you confirm that the question "Will a member of the National League for Democracy (NLD) take office as president of Myanmar before April 2016?" refers to April 2016 in the US Pacific Time Zone, rather than before April 2016 in Mayanmar? There are news reports that the transition will occur on April 1, and I don't want my forecast to be wrong based on a time zone confusion.
Thanks! Response 1: Thank you for your question. You are correct that we typically use Pacific Time Zone to define deadlines but I'll raise the issue with team and let you know if we have any additional guidance on this specific case. Response 2: Just wanted to send a note to follow up. We discussed the issue and will indeed follow our standard deadlines and will use the Pacific Time Zone to resolve the question. In general we try to avoid setting deadlines where the time zone will be determinative but sometimes it happens.  My assumption has been as long as this happens early in the day it counts but I'm not super confident, thus 85%.

This question does not ask whether a member of the NLD will be elected as president before April. It asks wether a member of the NLD will take office as president before April. In Myanmar,  that are two hugely different things, as mentioned in the description: The parlamentary elections were conducted in November. It took until February for the elected members of the parliament to take office. So the "take office" part is the interesting one here. The new president will likely be elected in March, but he will seemingly only take office on April 1. April 1 has been circulating since some weeks and been mentioned by the office of the president as the date for the transfer of power now. Or at least by a speaker of the office. According to a report (yes, some uncertainity here). I also asked a Journalist from Myanmar and the date seems pretty fixed according to him (besides that there are no official candidates yet of course & nobody, including myself, guaantees anything AND March 31 continues to pop up on some pages >_> ). Note that before the March 17 nomination-date was set, it has been regarded widely as self-evident that the new president would be nominated &  elected in February "as one of the first acts of the parliament". Note further, that the new parliament also did not taker over immediately from the old one alhough this indeed happened a bit faster than expected. How did this question develop so wrong?
According to an extensive ICC report (from the end of 2015) on the election in Myanmar, president Thein Sein term ends on March 30 and he was correspondingly expected to step down on March 30.  The successor needed to take office on March 31 (no clue why there is a gap of one day, but that's how it was planned according to the news paper reports. I expect it's a ceremonial-thing.). That was the situation when the question was posted and thus the question maked sense (I started with 90%, then raised it to 99% through december, then started to drop it; raised it again and then kept it down...). However, Thein Sein decided to step down on March 31 in the meanwhile (around the end of december; no reason at all), thus moving the date for the inauguration of the new president to March 31 or, more likely, to April 1. I wondered if they just thought that having no president for one night might be strange and thus both events have been rearranged to the same day. If April 1 is correct now, that wasn't the case. But hasn't a time window of one day (or maybe less) always been way too foggy to justify such a high consensus? ------------------------------------- I asked the GJ-Crew for clarification on the election/take office issue (@austerity @ulfelder)

Parliament has set a deadline of March 17 for the lower and upper house, along with the military bloc, to submit their nominations for the presidency. For instance, crucial events and the role of opposition figures other than Aung San Suu Kyi are often ignored or trivialised. A case in point is U Nu, the former prime minister of Burma who had been ousted by General Ne Win in a coup d’état in 1962. At the height of the uprising in 1988, U Nu had tried to form an interim coalition government with Aung San Suu Kyi and other opposition figures based on his legitimacy as the last democratically-elected prime minister. His initiative collapsed after Aung San Suu Kyi outright rejected it arguing that the “future of the opposition will be decided by the masses of the people” (64) and, in the following, Popham ridicules U Nu as an “inveterate opportunist” (157). However, Aung San Suu Kyi's dismissal of U Nu's initiative at that pivotal moment in 1988 when the regime was utterly shaky, troops started to change sides, and India's prime minister Rajiv Gandhi had signalled his readiness to recognise the interim government, was arguably a major strategic mistake." ...thus Suu Kyi has a record of screwing up from winning positions, largely out of an unwillingness to compromise, and there are unpromising signs that she might well do so here again.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-myanmar-politics-idUSKCN0VB1ES From the  article "Suu Kyi has said she will rule "above the president", but has given few details about her plans, fuelling speculation about figurehead presidential candidates or legal devices to allow her to lead the new government when a lengthy transition is completed at the end of March.
One such device would be to temporarily suspend article 59 (f), a move first floated by prominent lawmaker and former general Aung Ko. He is a close friend of Shwe Mann, the former speaker of parliament purged from the junta-linked Union Solidarity and Development Party last year and now a key Suu Kyi ally.
Such a temporary suspension, the thinking goes, could allow Suu Kyi to become president without formally changing the constitution, which requires the votes of more than three-quarters of parliamentarians - so giving the military, which holds 25 percent of seats, a veto - and a national referendum.
While Myanmar's post-independence 1947 constitution allowed for the suspension of articles, the 2008 charter, which has been criticized as vague and open to interpretation, makes no mention of it. "In our constitution, there's no provision saying whether or not 59 (f) can be suspended," Aung Ko told local media in December. "In such a case, the law can be suspended."
LEGAL GREY AREA
Ko Ni, the NLD's legal expert, as well as Nyan Win, a senior NLD official and Suu Kyi's legal advisor, said they thought the parliament could suspend the article with a simple majority. "There is an informal way (to amend the constitution) in which we have to enact a special law to temporarily suspend the provision in 59 (f). This law can be enacted by 51 percent of votes at the Union Parliament," said Ko Ni.
It was unclear whether the top NLD ranks are planning to table such a proposal. Nyan Win, a CEC member, and Ko Ni said they did not know of such plans.
Win Htein, a former political prisoner and one of the party's most influential leaders, declined to comment, but told Reuters it would announce its presidential candidate next week.
Ye Htut, Information Minister and spokesman for the outgoing President Thein Sein, said a constitutional article could only be suspended in a state of emergency, with executive powers transferred to the army chief.Such a step would also set a bad precedent for the country's burgeoning democracy, he added in an interview with Reuters. "Now the NLD suspends one article, what happens after 2020, another party comes in and they suspend another 10 articles or 12 articles? So what will happen to our country?" said Ye Htut.
The military-owned Myawady daily said in an editorial coinciding with the inauguration of parliament on Monday that it opposed any changes to the constitution.
"The head of the state should be someone who the entire people can trust without any doubt," said the editorial. "Therefore, the family members of the head of the state should not be ones who are entitled to enjoy the rights and privileges of a subject of a foreign country."

Selection of the president requires (by the constitution of 2008) that elected representatives of the Lower House, the elected representatives of the Upper House, and the unelected army representatives vote on nominations for president. This process could however be complicated by the role of the military and safeguards provided in the constitution.

There are two main sources of uncertainty here: 1) the risk of a reactionary coup aimed at aborting the transfer of power (a la Algeria in 1991), and 2) the possibility that the presidential election process will produce a non-partisan compromise candidate. I think the risk of (1) is quite low at this point, and will stay low as long as the NLD does not immediately pursue a transformative or retributive agenda. I understand (2) less well but believe there is only a modest chance of it as well. So I am starting at 90% and will move primarily in response to signals or new information affecting those two things.

This is a tricky question. I believe she'll overwhelmingly be voted in as president, but she can't assume the seat due to constitutional restrictions. The NLD must change the constitution first. First meaning that she is actually declared president regardless of being voted into office. "A clear parliamentary majority for the main opposition party would enable Suu Kyi to form a government, even though she is prevented by the constitution from assuming the presidency. Tin Oo, an NLD founding member, told the Nikkei Asian Review that amending the 2008 constitution -- which also provides the military a veto-wielding 25% bloc of seats in parliament -- remains top of the NLD agenda." "Any change to the constitution -- strongly opposed by the military -- would require a super-majority of 75% in parliament." I don't think all of this will happen before our deadline of April 2016.

The Parliament will choose three candidates. The military, with its guaranteed 25% share of parliamentary seats, will select one, but the NLD (with about 60%) will have the other two, and therefore the Presidency (while the other two become Vice-Presidents). The current President, retired General Thein Sein, is making all the right noises, so it seems very unlikely the military won't hand over power, having been planning this for years and building in many safeguards to protect their interests. Aung San Suu Kyi has already  accepted that she won't be the first president by saying she will rule "above the President". Based on current discussions, I don't see any impediment to an NLD President taking office in March 2016 (so long as there aren't any last-minute delays).

The party was hugely successful in the last election, but the question could be complicated by issues related to the constitutional prohibition that  prevents Aung San Suu Kyi from becoming president.

I am fairly confident, that a member of the NLD will become president before April 2016. According to schedule, the current government will remain in place until the end of February 2016. The NLD won over 80 percent of the seats in then national parliament. Though a fixed military presence remains, the NLD gets to choose the president. Outgoing President Thein Sein pledged to recognize the will of the people and said: "All duties would be transferred to the next government systematically according to the schedule. We will make sure it will be smooth and stable without having to worry about anything." However - and this may be the only obstacle - Aung San Suu Kyi is banned by the constitution to take over the presidency. She repeatedly declared, that a solution for that could be found and she would make all decisions anyway. That can mean two things: Either Aung San Suu Kyi aims at amending the consitution or at selecting a loyal replacement. Both options could prove to be time consuming, since she either way would need the support of the parliament and the issues could brake party lines. While the horizont of the question only leaves a timetable of one month (March) for the election of a president, these issues are being discussed by the NLD since weeks and I assume they will find a solution in time to avoid a troublesome start after this groundbreaking election.
